USD/CHN stands right around 6.568. The exchange rate hasn't been below 6.3 since its big three day run up in August. Since then the RMB's biggest daily rise was from about 6.47 to a around 6.385 in early September. A quick scouring of the charts shows an average trading day movement since then has been less than a third of that open to close. There has been virtually no movement on any period from late afternoon on Fridays (EST) to Sunday afternoons (EST). Given that it is now 15:25 EST on a Friday there is little reason to think there will be much movement in the next day.  The only thing that seems to move the RMB a required amount on any given day is a change in the trading band as set each day by the PBOC. I can find no record of them doing this on a weekend. The currency markets don't technically close. There is just extremely limited liquidity so, unlike stock markets, big moves are still possible. Given that tomorrow is a holiday in many parts of the world an announement of that nature before the deadline moves up even higher above 99% than it already was for me.  Furthermore, instability in Chinese markets has been a massive preoccupation for Chinese officials this year after all of the instability in their main stock markets this year. This pushes the needle even further towards 0% that an announcement of this kind will be made before the deadline.  One caveat: One November 4, 2015, Bloomberg published an article about the PBOC publishnig some 5 month old comments from governor Zhou Xiaochuan as if they were new. This seems to have mainly impacted stock indexes, though. If they were to somehow misrelease an old change in the trading band then I suppose a massive change in the currency rate could ensue. If I could assign a probability of 0.01% to 6.3 or below I would.  Instead, I rounded down.  I also rounded down to 0% for the next two ranges.  For 6.35 to 6.4 I may have assigned a probability of about 0.05%.  Barring any PBOC blunders it seems nothing less than an above ground nuclear test by North Korea could do much to roil markets so much in the next 24 hours or so. Even then, you would have to assume that the PBOC would either be so overwhelmed that they couldn't protect their band or that they got out a statement in time on a weekend. None of this adds up to anywhere near 0.5% probability for me and so no need to round up to 1% in any category. Note added January 07, 2016 (seven days after closing): Talk about needing to test even one's most basic assumptions. When I made this post I thought it was Friday when it was in fact Thursday. Although this fact would not have moved me from 0% it underscores for me that no assumption can be too basic to test.

Data from 1981-2015 (34 years) shows the following: 
USD/CNY < 6.3 = 1981-1993, but I'm heavily discounting this since the period is from more than 2 decades ago 
USD/CNY between 6.3 and 6.35 = 9 months in the past 
USD/CNY between 6.35-6.40 = 4 months in the past 
USD/CNY > 6.4 = 1994 - 2011, moderately discounting this Ever since the Yuan devaluation in Aug 12 2015, the pair has surged from 6.2 to 6.39, which the latter has become the "new normal" so a greater emphasis should be on C and D. the pair has been hovering at C from Aug 12 to Dec 4, and shooting up to D range from Dec 4 to Dec 28. 
The reason for this is most likely the end ZIRP in the US, luring money towards USD-denominated assets as investors have been pricing in for the rate hike. 
Another major factor is due to the Yuan being officially included the the IMF's SDR, which the pair began to accelerate after Nov 30.

Today is my first forecast for this question - I am late to the game. The current exchange rate is 6.4807 (Dec 21). In 10 days, I am estimating that there is only a 11% chance it falls below 6.40. This is based on the (very) few things I know about the yuan / USD exchange rate, namely:
(1) The yuan is a "managed float" currency. The exchange rate is largely controlled by the Chinese government, and is under-going a managed devaluation to stimulate export growth due to a weakening economy.
(2)  On Nov 30, the yuan entered the IMF's selective basket of reserve currencies, and the Chinese government has vowed to keep the yuan stable
So the question becomes: What is the likelihood of the government to reverse the current devaluation strategy, in the next 10 days, so that the exchange rate falls below 6.40 USD?
Frankly, if all my assumptions are right, then it will be even more unlikely than I have estimated here. However, there's still a lot I don't know on this topic, so I've left room to allow for my ignorance. *Like you, I'm learning to forecast. The hardest part is coming up with your very first forecast, particularly if you know very little - like for this question. https://superforecasting.squarespace.com*

In the last month the renminbi has been increasing it's value from 6.37 to 6.46. in 2015 (even including the surge in August) it has remained between 6.2 and today's maximum. And looking at the last 5 years, it has oscillated between 6.06 and 6.66. This shows that the volatility of the renminbi has been relatively low - at least compared with other currencies, such as the Mexican Peso for instance that has experienced much bigger changes. This despite significant manipulation from both the Chinese and US governments over their currencies. If lots of things were priced in SDRs, the IMF’s decision would have forced companies around the world to buy yuan-denominated assets as soon as possible, to hedge their exposure. That would have prompted China’s currency to strengthen dramatically. But few goods or services are priced in SDRs. Instead, admission to the currency club is significant mainly for its symbolism: the IMF is lending its imprimatur to the yuan as a reserve currency—a safe, liquid asset in which governments can park their wealth. Indeed, far from setting off a groundswell of demand for the yuan, the IMF’s decision may pave the way for the yuan’s depreciation.
[...]
Though still far from being a free-floating currency—the central bank has intervened since August to prop the yuan up—the cost of such intervention is now higher. The PBOC must spend real money during the trading day to guide the yuan to its desired level. Inclusion in the SDR will only deepen expectations that China let market forces decide the yuan’s exchange rate. The point of the SDR is to weave disparate currencies together into a single, diversified unit; some have suggested, for example, that commodities be quoted in SDRs to reduce the volatility of pricing them in dollars. But if China maintains its de facto peg to the dollar, the result of adding the yuan to the SDR will be to boost the dollar’s weight in the basket, undermining its purpose. What would happen if China really did give the market the last word on the yuan? For some time it has been under downward pressure. The simplest yardstick is the decline in China’s foreign-exchange reserves, from a peak of nearly $4 trillion last year to just over $3.5 trillion now, a reflection, in part, of the PBOC’s selling of dollars to support the yuan. Were it not for tighter capital controls since the summer, outflows might have been even bigger. And the yuan does look overvalued. Despite China’s slowing economy, the yuan’s continued link to the surging dollar has put it near an all-time high in trade-weighted terms, up by more than 13% in the past 18 months. With the Federal Reserve set to start raising interest rates, at the same time as China is loosening its monetary policy, the yuan is likely to come under more downward pressure, at least against the dollar. It would be foolhardy to predict that China will suddenly give the market totally free rein. That would go against its deep-seated preference for gradual reform. But while basking in the glow of its SDR status, China must also be aware of the responsibility to minimise currency intervention that comes with it. A weaker yuan may well be the result.

The central bank stepped up efforts last month to avert that risk with a sixth interest-rate cut in a year. While easier policy helps tide over the short term, a long-term fix needs leaders to back reforms in the 13th five-year plan that slash excess industrial capacity, rev up new growth drivers and shift funding away from deadbeat state companies to vibrant private ones. China’s total outstanding borrowing has surged by two-thirds since 2008 to 208 percent of gross domestic product, producer prices have slumped for 43 consecutive months and the consumer price index began a downward trajectory in the middle of last year. FOREX predictions are often a tale of tears, but there will almost certainly not be any dramatic change in the dollar-renminbi exchange rate by this date.   The renminbi doesn't float freely.  In recent times, it would hardly change at all over the course of a year.  The exchange rate is manipulated by the Chinese government officials for three contradictory purposes.  (1) They want an undervalued currency to promote exports.  (2) They aspire to have the  renminbi become a reserve currency in the future.  (3) They have an internal political imperative to preserve the belief that they have absolute control over everything.  Recent information now suggests that the ECB will pursue a looser monetary policy, putting downward pressure on the Euro over time.  This will mess up Chinese goal #1 and create pressure for another Chinese devaluation.  However, the most recent devaluation episode made them lose face with respect to goals #2 and #3.   They also have a potentially dangerous political showdown coming up regarding territorial claims in the South China Sea.  They won't want to show weakness with respect to the exchange rate while they are playing the bully role with respect to the first island chain.   The only problem here is that 6.36 is on the bubble between two artificial choices.  The correct answer is somewhat more likely to be (C) than (B) since that would favor Chinese goal #1

As I write this, the spot rate is 6.37.  If this rate had been totally free-floating and there were no other factors to consider, you would expect the rate on 1/1/16 to be 6.37*(1+3% annual rate difference btw currencies / 365 * 92 days) = 6.42 on that day based on interest rate parity. HOWEVER, the PBOC has been quickly depleting reserves in order to hold the yuan this strong, while the USD has appreciated dramatically over the last year and a half against basically all currencies.  The credit cycle in China has seemed to enter a downtrend over the last few months or more.  Property values had also started to downtrend, but easing measures in that regard have flattened the downtrend for the last few months.  While China has tons of reserves and enormous capacity to ease in many, many ways, all the methods of easing lead to increased devaluation pressure on the renminbi.  Devaluation itself will help China cushion its fall, and I'm not sure why the PBOC has been so stubborn about seeing that, but at some point the market should/will overwhelm the PBOC's strengthening efforts. Another thing to consider is that even within the recent band of movement, at 6.37 the renminbi is on the strong side, so even ignoring the longer-term factors, it will likely be back over 6.4 soon.  6.3-6.4 is quite a narrow band, so that range is the least probable in my opinion. I also am not so bullish on the USD.  The USD has appreciated so much in the last year and a half apparently b/c they have announced an intent to tighten monetary policy while the rest of the world loosens further while we veer towards global deflation.  I think the Fed will have to veer back towards easing, eventually, as well, which will take the USD down. Also, b/c the interest rate for renminbi is higher than that for the USD, the USD strenthens in a "risk-off" situation relative to the renminbi.  So if the world continues on the recent general "risk off" direction, this will heap pressure on the renminbi to devalue. The PBOC could decide to temporarily screw over the market/speculators by moving the rate further in a strong direction.  Also, China's property market could start to ignite again or the USD may weaken, which may take pressure off selling the renminbi,  so I assume the probability that it's under 6.3 at ~15-20%. I should note that I'm very short the renminbi right now.  I put my money where my mouth is when I can.

There's several opposing factors here. - China is currently spending $100 billion per month (!) to support the RMB from further weakening. Even with $3.5 trillion in foreign exchange holdings, that's a lot.
- Money is flowing out of China, largely because there's nothing perceived as safe to invest it in, internally.
- China wants in to the IMF breadbasket currency, and the IMF wants wider trading bands so that the RMB "floats" at a fair market rate.
- The US (China's largest customer) is putting pressure on China to strengthen the RMB, due to balance of trade issues.
- Every other economy in the world is doing their best to weaken their own currency.
- The USD may go in either direction due to market perception, as a result of the Fed interest rate call(s) later this year. As a result, this is an exceptionally difficult question to call accurately. My initial guess is that the RMB will weaken before it strengthens (i.e. I'm putting P=0.5 on option D). The direction may well reverse before the end of the year, so I'll have to keep a close eye on this.

This is likely to spook global markets further.  As China gains more success in promoting the renminbi to other foreign central banks, the mere substitution of US dollar for renminbi would act as a stop to the freefall of the currency. Once included into the SDR, the renminbi will also gain seigniorage value as a reserve currency China’s latest currency decisions have indeed been, at least in part, a bid to internationalise its currency. For three days in a row last month, the PBoC devalued the renminbi in its daily fixing against the US dollar by 1.8% on 11 August, 1.6%, on 12 August, and 1.1% on 13 August – a total of 4.5% in three days (see chart).  Market participants who initially saw the PBoC’s announcement as a liberalisation move rather than one of devaluation were subsequently convinced there was some degree of the latter intended by policymakers. But, in our view, the two objectives hold equal weight – the need to switch to a free market mechanism and second, the need to revive growth. There has been a question about the Chinese currency’s official exchange rate, being a true market rate given the actual spot market was trading nowhere close to it. Hence, it was inevitable that the PBoC had to ‘fix its fixing’. It also seems clear that the move was implicitly sanctioned by the IMF, as evidenced by a statement the day after to say it welcomes the PBoC’s move and that the consequent devaluation of the renminbi would not impact the SDR decision.
